text: Jesus fuck, if you infect your kids with chicken pox you're not tough or edgy or free-range or traditionalist or whatever; you're an awful fucking human being who enjoys torturing your own children.
author: drfarls

text: The kid who got sick barely complained, and missed only two days of school.  Because vaccines.
author: drfarls

text: Turns out that the vaccine didn't fully work in the case of one of my girls, and she got the chicken pox.  My other daughter didn't.  I wrote about it here.
author: drfarls

text: I had chicken pox as a kid.  Got it from my sister, who got it from my cousin.  It sucked.  For two weeks, basically torture.   Escaped without any scars, but missed a week and a half of school.  God did it suck.
author: drfarls

text: So a few years back, I decided to have my kids vaccinated against chicken pox.  And I did, because I'm not a goddamn sadist.

text: In the 1980s Cold War ideological conflict and general post-colonial solidarity made it a rough go for Israel.  But we're way past that now, and the semi-authoritarian in Jerusalem has good relations with Modi, Putin, and Xi.

text: Something else to watch for: These leprechaun producers are going to pressuring London *hard* on the terms "organic" and "free range."  So weirdly enough if you really want organic free range leprechaun meat in your Lucky Charms your best bet might be Chinese.
author: drfarls

text: Idea being that as soon as the EU is out of the mix, they'll be able to take advantage of the US market again.  In my view it has to happen quick, though, and May isn't doing them any favors by delaying.
author: drfarls

text: What I've heard from industry insiders is that Brexit may have a big impact on this.  While industrial leprechaun farming was mainly concentrated in the south and southeast, there are some people working on establishing sites in Northern Ireland for mass leprechaun processing.
author: drfarls

text: Little known fact: While the United States used to import leprechaun meat primarily from Ireland, regulatory changes mandated by Dublin's EU membership required a shift to Chinese producers.  And with Trump's trade war, this is what we get.
